In this work, a series of carbon nitride (CN) doped wV x O y /CN-SBA-15 (w = 0.5–4.8%) catalysts were prepared. The doping of CN could significantly enhance the activity of V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalyst due to the synergistic effect of V species, CN and SBA-15. The 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 was identified as the most optimum catalyst, offering a high EL conversion (93.0%) and EP selectivity (98.7%) at 130 °C after 3 h of reaction. The O2-TPD and H2-TPR results confirmed that the redox properties of 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 are significantly improved compared with 2.7 V x O y /SBA-15, which plays an important role in the oxidation reaction. In addition, the control experiments indicated that the pyridinic-N rather than pyrrolic-N of the VxOy/CN-SBA-15 catalyst accelerated the oxidation of EL to EP. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Ethyl lactate Ethyl pyruvate Oxidation reaction Carbon nitride Vanadia Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Catalytic conversion of biomass platform molecular into value-added chemicals and liquid fuels is one of the effective ways to replace the current production of chemicals using fossil energy as the feedstock [1]. For example, lactic acid and lactate as important biomass platform molecules could be easily obtained through the fermentation of biomass resources (cellulose, starch, sugars, and glycerol, etc.), which can be further converted to many fine chemicals such as acrylic acid, acrylate, lactide, and pyruvate [2–6]. Among them, pyruvate as an important chemical intermediate has been widely used in food additives, plastics, drugs, and other fields, and thus obtained much attention [7,8]. Commercially, pyruvate is mainly produced by the dehydration and decarboxylation of tartaric acid, in which a large amount of KHSO4 is required as a dehydrating agent, resulting in environmental pollution [9]. Direct catalytic oxidation of lactate to pyruvate is one of the most promising methods. In addition, the structure of lactate is similar to that of pyruvate and thus has a higher atomic efficiency by this oxidation route. The production of pyruvate by oxidative dehydrogenation of lactate has been widely reported in both gas-phase and liquid-phase reactions over various solid catalysts. Very recently, Lu et al. [10] prepared a Cu/SiO2-HP (hydrolysis–precipitation method) catalyst with highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles for the gas-phase oxidation of ethyl lactate (EL) to ethyl pyruvate (EP), an 85.4% EL conversion and 91.1% EP selectivity was obtained at 320 °C under O2-free conditions. The synergistic effect of the Cu0/Cu+ interface activates the O-H and C-H bonds of the reactant. They also found that cesium-exchanged Al-rich Beta zeolite (Cs-Beta) was very effective for the oxidation of methyl lactate (ML) to methyl pyruvate (MP), and the yield of methyl lactate was 87.4% (full methyl lactate conversion) at 340 °C [5]. In the gas phase, a higher reaction temperature (above 200 °C) was required to vaporize the feedstock, and the higher temperature not only increased the production cost but also formed more side products. From the economic point of view, it is important to develop an efficient solid catalyst for liquid phase oxidation of lactate to pyruvate under mild conditions. Chu et al. [11] prepared a series of noble-metal catalysts such as Pt/AC, Pd/AC, Rh/AC, Ru/AC, and Au/AC and applied them in the liquid-phase oxidation of ML to MP. Among these catalysts, Ru/AC showed the highest EP selectivity (ca. 90%), while the EL conversion was only 19.4%. The kinetic study based on the Langir-Hinshelwood model indicated that the surface reaction between adsorbed mL and oxygen of Ru/AC was the rate-determining step of the reaction. Considering the high cost of noble-metal catalysts, non-precious metal catalysts have been widely prepared and used in this reaction. For example, Wang et al. [12] used oxidized multi-wall carbon nanotube (oCNT) as catalysts for the oxidation of EL to EP reaction using TBHP as the oxidant, giving a 39% EL conversion and 93.6% EP selectivity at 90 °C in 6 h. Although TBHP as an oxidant can efficiently catalyze the lactate to pyruvate, it is easy to decompose at high temperatures, which increases the difficulty of product separation·H2O2 and O2 as the cheap and green oxidants are also widely used in this oxidation reaction. Lu et al. [13] reported the oxidation of EL to EP over TS-1 zeolite using H2O2 (30 wt%) as the oxidant, achieving a 97.8% EP yield at 50 °C after 9 h. Based on the kinetic analysis, they found that the formation of Ti(OOH) is the rate-determining step. Zhang et al. [14] found that the EL conversion and EP selectivity were significantly improved when pyridine-type additives were added to the reaction solution. They thus loaded the vanadia sites on a pyridine–rich carbonaceous support and this catalyst gives a 90% EP selectivity at 80% EL conversion at 130 °C and 1 atm oxygen. Very recently, Tong’s group reported that using a trace of HBr (ca. 0.009 equiv.) as the homogeneous catalyst, a 99% EP yield was obtained after 4 h in the presence of O2 under visible light [15]. Although many catalysts have been applied in the oxidation of lactate to pyruvate reaction, developing effective catalysts with high pyruvate selectivity at low temperatures and short time is still essential. It is known that doping nitrogen to carbon materials can improve oxidation reactions due to the action of pyridinic or pyrrolic nitrogen groups [14,16,17]. In this work, carbon nitride was doped into the V x O y /SBA-15 catalyst by a post-impregnation method and used for the oxidation of EL to EP. The conversion of EL increased with increasing the vanadia loading, while the selectivity of EP was almost unchanged. The results also showed that the doping of carbon nitride significantly increased the activity of the V x O y /SBA-15 catalyst, and the EL conversion increased from 61.6% of 2.7 V x O y /SBA-15 to 93% of 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalyst. The results of O2-TPD and H2-TPR showed that the doping of carbon nitride improved the reducibility of V x O y /SBA-15 catalysts. In addition, the nitrogen-containing additive (pyridine or pyrrole) was also added to the reaction solution to study the role of CN. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The SBA-15 was synthesized according to our previous report [18,19] (see Supporting Information for details). The wV x O y /CN-SBA-15 was prepared by a two-step impregnation method. The first impregnation step: a certain amount of dicyandiamide was dissolved into 20 mL ethanol, and 1 g of SBA-15 was added to the above solution and then stirred for 30 min at room temperature. The above solution was then heated to 80 °C to remove ethanol. The obtained power was finally calcined at a specified temperature for 4 h in a Muffle furnace and denoted as CN-SBA-15. The second impregnation step was similar to the first step: a certain amount of VO(acac)2 was dissolved in 20 mL ethanol, 1 g of CN-SBA-15 was added to above solution, followed by stirring, drying, and calcination, and denoted as wV x O y /CN-SBA-15_m_T. where the w, m and T refer to the weight loading of V (0.5–5%), mass ratio of CN to SBA-15 (0.04–0.9) and calcination temperature (300–500 °C), respectively. Unless specified, the mass ratio of CN to SBA-15 was 0.45, and the calcination temperature was 400 °C. It should be noted that the calcination temperature of these two steps was the same. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The properties of catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption–desorption technique, Fourier transforms infrared (FTIR) spectra, Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), O2-temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) and H2-temperature-programmed reduction (TPR). Detailed analytic methods are provided in the Supporting Information. 2.3 Catalytic reaction The oxidation reaction of EL was performed in a stainless-steel autoclave. Typically, 50 mg catalyst, 2 mmol EL, and 15 mL CH3CN were added into the autoclave, respectively. The reactor was then sealed and introduced 0.8 MPa O2 into the autoclave after purging with O2 three times. The reactor was then heated to the reaction temperature under stirring. After the reaction, the reactor was immediately cooled, and the products were analyzed by GC equipped with an FFAP capillary column and a flame ionization detector. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Materials Characterization 3.1.1 Structural characterization We first investigated the structural characteristics of the prepared catalysts. Fig. 1a shows the small-angle XRD of the parent SBA-15, CN-SBA-15, and V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalysts. It can be seen that all samples showed three diffraction peaks, corresponding to the (100), (110), and (200) planes of SBA-15 [18–20]. While no reflection of carbon nitride and vanadium species appeared in the CN-SBA-15 and V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalysts. This may be because the carbon nitride and vanadium species were highly dispersed on SBA-15 or the loading of carbon nitride and vanadium species was very low. In addition, the XRD results also showed that the ordered structure of SBA-15 was not destroyed after loading with carbon nitride and vanadium species. SEM images also showed that the morphology of SBA-15 did not change after loading carbon nitride and/or vanadium species ( Fig. 2). The porous properties of the prepared catalysts were analyzed by N2-adsorption-desorption and the results were shown in Fig. 1b. The parent SBA-15 showed type-IV isotherm with an H1 hysteresis loop at P/P0 around 0.70–0.85, suggesting that the SBA-15 is a highly ordered mesoporous material, which is consistent with the literature [21,22]. The curves of CN-SBA-15 and V x O y /CN-SBA-15 samples were similar to those of SBA-15, suggesting that the structure of SBA-15 was not damaged after loading carbon nitride or/and vanadium. The 2.7 V x O y /CN presented an IV isotherm with an H1 hysteresis loop at a higher P/P0 = 0.80–1.0. Moreover, the pore size distribution of these SBA-15-based samples was narrow and concentrated at about 9.5 nm (Fig. 1c). The specific BET surface area, pore volumes, and pore diameter are listed in Table 1. The SBA-15 showed the highest surface area (607 m2 g−1) and pore volumes (1.06 cm3 g−1), and gradually decreased with the increase of V x O y loading. The pore diameter of these samples was around 9.5 nm, except for V x O y /CN-SBA-15 samples (9.06 nm). As expected, the V x O y /CN showed the lowest surface area (19 m2 g−1), pore volumes (0.05 cm3 g−1), and Pore diameter (2.7 nm), these values are consistent with the results of CN in the literature [23–25]. In addition, the actual V loading was also measured by ICP and the results are listed in Table 1. FTIR analysis was then performed for all wV x O y /CN-SBA-15 samples to analyze the chemical functional group of these samples (Fig. 1d). For comparison, the FTIR of parent SBA-15 and pure CN were also presented. For CN and 2.7 V x O y /CN samples, the peak located at approximately 800 cm−1 was attributed to the breathing mode of heptazine units; the several bands in 1200 to 1600 cm−1 corresponded to the stretching vibration of aromatic CN heterocycles; and the broad peaks around 3200 cm−1 were ascribed to the stretching vibrations of amino group and adsorbed water [26,27]. For SBA-15 support, three obvious peaks at about 470, 800, and 1080 cm−1 corresponded to the Si–O–Si vibrations of SBA-15; and a small peak at 970 cm−1was also found, which is attributed to the Si-OH group of SBA-15. It should be noted that small peaks at 1200 to 1600 cm−1 were also observed in V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalysts, indicating that the CN was successfully loaded on SBA-15. While, the peak of heptazine units in V x O y /CN-SBA-15 overlaps with the Si–O–Si vibrations in SBA-15. FTIR results also indicated that the framework of SBA-15 was not damaged after loading CN and vanadium species, which is consistent with the data of small-angle XRD. To characterize the compositions and valence state of V x O y /CN-SBA-15, the XPS was performed. It can be seen from the survey scan that the spectrum of CN-SBA-15 showed five clear peaks with the binding energies of 532, 400, 286, 150, and 103 eV, corresponding to the O 1 s, N 1 s, C 1 s, Si 2 s and Si 2p, respectively (Fig. 1e). The V 2p spectra was also observed in all V x O y /CN-SBA-15 samples, indicating that the vanadium species was successfully loaded on SBA-15. Moreover, the signal located at 398 eV, associated with the nitrogen element, was also detected in the spectra of V x O y /CN-SBA-15 (Fig. 1e inset), confirming that the nitrogen carbon has been successfully supported on the surface of SBA-15. The high-resolution V 2p spectra of 4.8 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 and V2O5 were further recorded to elucidate the chemical environment of V species on CN-SBA-15 and the results were presented in Fig. S1. Both the spectra showed two signals at about 524 and 517 eV, corresponded to 2p1/2 and 2p 3/2 orbits of V species. For the 4.8 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 sample, the position of these two peaks shifted to lower binding energies compared to V2O5, indicating the interaction between V and CN-SBA-15. Similar results have also been found in other supported vanadia catalysts [18,28]. In order to characterize the valence state of V, the deconvoluted V 2p3/2 spectra of V x O y /CN-SBA-15 were presented in Fig. 1f. The V2p3/2 spectra can be divided into two peaks, the binding energy of 515.7 and 517.1 eV are ascribed to V4+ and V5+, respectively. In addition, the ratio of V4+/(V4++V5+) was also calculated and listed in the last column of Table 1. The percentage of V4+ first increased from 0.43 to 0.52 with increasing the V loading from 0.5 to 1.0% and then decreased to 0.33 when the V loading further increased to 4.8%. The effect of the V4+/(V4++V5+) on catalytic performance will be discussed in the next section. 3.1.2 Redox properties The redox properties of the prepared catalysts were then characterized by O2-TPD and H2-TPR, and the results are shown in Fig. 3. The O2-TPD experiment is the main method to analyze the oxygen capture and release of the sample. Typically, the physical adsorption oxygen (O2(ad)) is first desorbed from the catalyst surface at a relatively low temperature. With the increase in temperature, chemically adsorbed oxygen (O2- (ad) and O- (ad)) and lattice oxygen (O2- (latt)) are gradually desorbed from the surface of the catalyst [29–31]. It can be seen that curves of V2O5, V x O y /SBA-15, and V x O y /CN-SBA-15 are different (Fig. 3a). For V2O5, a very small peak at about 150 °C was observed, corresponding to the desorption of O2(ad). With the increase in temperature, the O2- (latt) started desorption at 700 °C and reached the maximum at about 740 °C. After loading 2.7%V x O y on SBA-15, the peak areas of O2(ad) and O2- (latt) increased significantly, indicating that the amount of O2(ad) and O2- (latt) increased. On the other hand, the initial desorption temperature and peak temperature of O2- (latt) decreased from 700 to 500 °C and 740 to 730 °C, respectively, confirming that the activity of O2- (latt) was improved. When CN was further doped to 2.6 V x O y /SBA-15, the peak area of O2- (latt) was further increased, and the peak temperature was significantly reduced from 730 to 675 °C, suggesting that the oxidation properties of catalysts were further improved. Moreover, the amount of O2 desorption from the catalyst surface was also calculated and the results were listed in Table 2. The V2O5 showed the lowest amount of O2 desorption (0.6 mmol/gcat). When 2.7% V x O y was loaded on SBA-15, the O2 desorption amount increased to 5.9 mmol/gcat, and further increased to 9.1 mmol/gcat when CN was doped on V x O y /SBA-15 catalyst. These data also showed that the oxidation properties were significantly improved after CN was doped on V x O y /SBA-15 catalyst. The reducibility of the prepared catalysts was also studied by H2-TPR measurement (Fig. 3b). It can be seen that the bulk V2O5 has three H2 consumption peaks, corresponding to the valence changes of vanadia: V2O5 to V6O13 (685 °C), V6O13 to V2O4 (786 °C), and V2O4 to V2O3 (894 °C), respectively[32–34]. When 2.7 V x O y was supported on SBA-15, the H2 consumption peak merged into one peak and the peak shifted to a lower temperature (572 °C), which indicated that there was a strong interaction between V x O y and SBA-15. In addition, the peak intensity was significantly enhanced after CN was doped on V x O y /SBA-15, indicating that the reducibility of the catalyst has been improved. Similar results were also reported on other silica-supported vanadia catalysts [18,35–37]. It should be noted that due to the low content of V x O y (< 3%), it is understandable that the peak area of 2.7 V x O y /SBA-15 and 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 are smaller than that of V2O5. In addition, the V2O5 showed the highest H2 consumption, followed by 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 (0.54 mmol/gcat) and 2.7 V x O y /SBA-15 (0.36 mmol/gcat). Combined with the results of O2-TPD and H2-TPR, it can be seen that the redox properties of 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 are significantly improved compared with 2.7 V x O y /SBA-15, which plays an important role in the oxidation of EL to EP reaction. 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Activity evaluation of different catalysts Catalytic oxidative conversion of EL to EP reaction in the presence of molecular oxygen was carried out over synthesized catalysts, and the results are presented in Table 3. As anticipated, no EL conversion was observed over the CN-SBA-15 sample, indicating that CN could not catalyze this reaction. When V2O5 was used as the catalyst, a 30.5% EL conversion and 97.3% EP selectivity were achieved at 130 °C for 3 h. Doke et al. [38] also found that V2O5 could effectively catalyze EL to EP by using TBHP as the oxidant, however, significant TBHP decomposition was observed under the reaction conditions, which made it difficult to separate and purification of the target products. When 2.7% vanadia was supported on CN, the EL conversion seemed to decrease slightly, while the TOF significantly increased from 0.4 to 6.9, indicating that the proportion of vanadium available has increased. Moreover, the EL conversion increased to 61.6% after loading vanadia with SBA-15, possibly because the V x O y /SBA-15 has a much higher surface area than V x O y /CN (Table 1). When similar content of vanadia was supported on both CN and SBA-15 (2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15), the EL conversion was remarkably increased to 93.0%, indicating that the synergistic action of vanadia, CN, and SBA-15 improved the activity of catalyst. Specifically: Vanadia as the active site can catalyze the oxidation of EL to EP, CN acts as an additive, and SBA-15 provides a large surface area to support and disperse CN and vanadia species. In addition, the effect of VxOy loading on the catalytic performance was also performed. When a small amount of VxOy (ca. 0.5%) was loaded on CN-SBA-15, the EL conversion (26.8%) was even equal to that of 2.7 V x O y /CN (27.3%). With the VxOy content gradually increased to 4.8%, the EL conversion increased to 99.8%, while the TOF value first increased and then decreased, and reached the maximum when the V x O y loading was 1%. An attempt was then made to correlate the TOF with V4+/(V4++V5+) of 2.7 V x O y /SBA-15 and wV x O y /CN-SBA-15 (w = 0.5–4.8). Fig. 4 Shows that the TOF was positively correlated with the molar ratio of V4+/(V4++V5+). In general, the amount of V4+ ions are correlated with the oxidation reaction. A similar relationship was also observed over VxOy/SBA-15 [18] and mesoporous vanadia–titania catalysts for the same reaction [39]. The effect of time on the catalytic performance of all these wV x O y /CN-SBA-15 was also studied (Fig. S2). With the extension of time, the conversion of EL increased gradually. When the reaction time increased to 3 h, the value of EL conversion was similar on 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 and 4.8 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 samples. Thus, 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 was then used as the optimal catalyst to study the effect of reaction variables on the EL reaction. Moreover, it should be mentioned that the EP selectivity was always higher than 90% over all these catalysts, indicating that the vanadium-based catalysts have very high selectivity for EP. 3.2.2 Effect of reaction parameters The reaction temperature (100–130 °C) and time (0.5–3 h) on the EL reaction were then studied over 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalyst. It can be seen from Fig. 5a that the 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 has a high catalytic activity for EL conversion. A 4.5% EL conversion was obtained even at 100 °C for 0.5 h, and with the prolongation of reaction time to 3 h, the EL conversion increased to 34.9%. The reaction temperature also has a big influence on the catalytic performance of the catalyst, especially after 3 h of the reaction. When the reaction temperature increased from 100 to 130 °C, the EL conversion increased from 34.9 to 93%, respectively. A similar trend was also found in EP yield, and the values of EP yield were close to the EL conversion (Fig. 5b), suggesting that the selectivity of EP was always above 90% at different temperatures and times. The optimized reaction temperature and time were determined as 130 °C and 3 h, respectively. To get more insights into this reaction, the kinetics of this reaction on 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 was studied at four reaction temperatures of 100, 110, 120, and 130 °C. Due to the excess of CH3CN (n(CH3CN/EL) = 14.4), we assumed that the reaction rate was not affected by CH3CN concentration, but mainly by the concentration of EL. Fig. 5c shows the plot of ln(1-x) versus time for the EL to EP reaction over 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalyst, in which x is the conversion of EL. It is seen that the reaction can be regarded as pseudo-first-order kinetics, and the reaction rate constant (k) was estimated to be 0.1482, 0.2502, 0.5434, and 0.8363 h-1 for the temperatures 100, 110, 120, and 130, respectively. The activation energy (Ea) could be calculated from the dependence of k on reaction temperature via the Arrhenius equation, and the value of Ea was estimated to be 74.6 kJ/mol over 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalyst for the EL to EP reaction in the presence of molecular oxygen (Fig. 5d). It should be mentioned that V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalyst exhibit a lower Ea than that of V x O y /SBA-15 (84.8 kJ/mol)[18], indicating that the doping of carbon nitride may be more conducive to the oxidation of EL reaction. In addition, the Ea value was also much higher than other solid catalysts in the literature, such as TS-1 (103.4 kJ/mol) [13], and oCNT (119.1 kJ/mol) [12] catalyst. The effect of other variables such as catalyst production process (mass ratio of CN to SBA-15 and calcination temperature) and reaction conditions (atmosphere and catalyst weight) on the catalytic performance of 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalyst at 130 °C for 3 h were also studied, and the results were shown in Fig. 6. The mass ratio of CN to SBA-15 was controlled by fixing the amount of SBA-15 and changing the amount of dicyandiamide. To accurately study the effect of CN doping, other variables in the catalyst preparation process such as calcination temperature (400 °C) and vanadia loading (about 2.6%) were kept consistent. It can be seen from Fig. 6a that the mass ratio of CN to SBA-15 has a significant effect on the catalytic performance of the catalysts. When a small amount of CN was added to V x O y /SBA-15 (CN: SBA-15 = 0.038), the EL conversion and EP selectivity increased from 61.6 to 80% and 94.8 to 98.2%, respectively. With the further increase of CN amount, the EL conversion first increased and then decreased, and reached the maximum value (93%) when CN: SBA-15 = 0.45. The doping amount of CN has little effect on the selectivity of EP, and the EP selectivity is above 98% over all these catalysts, the improvement of catalytic performance may be related to the pyridinic or pyrrolic nitrogen groups in CN. However, the N1s peaks were very small in this study (Fig. 1e), making it difficult to calculate the amount of pyridinic or pyrrolic nitrogen in these V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalysts. On the other hand, the interaction between nitrogen species and active components (V x O y ) can effectively increase the dispersion of active species, and then improve their redox properties [40]. The calcination temperature is also an important factor affecting the catalytic performance of the catalyst. Fig. 6b shows the effect of calcination temperature (300–500 °C) on the catalytic performance of 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15. The results showed that the calcination temperature has a great effect on EL conversion, but little effect on EP selectivity (above 95%). When the calcination temperature was increased from 300 to 400 °C, the EL conversion increased from 41 to 93%; the EL conversion then dropped to 84% with increasing the calcination temperature to 500 °C. A similar trend was also observed on the V x O y /SBA-15 catalyst [18]. Thus, the optimum calcination temperature for EL to EP reaction on 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalyst is 400 °C. The effect of the atmosphere (N2, Air, and O2) was also studied on the catalytic performance of 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15, and the results were shown in Fig. 6c. A 6% EL conversion and 92% EP selectivity were achieved under N2 conditions. This may be because a small amount of molecular oxygen adsorbed on the catalyst. A low EL conversion was also observed under anaerobic conditions on other solid catalysts [18,41]. When air replaced N2 as the oxidant, the EL conversion and EP selectivity improved to 27% and 98%. Obviously, the highest EL conversion (93%) was obtained in the presence of pure oxygen, which may be due to the higher oxygen content than air. Therefore, molecular oxygen was the best oxidant for the EL to EP reaction. As expected, the catalyst weight has little effect on the EP selectivity, but a big effect on the EL conversion (Fig. 6d). When the catalyst weight was increased from 10 to 50 mg, the EL conversion increased from 47 to 93%. Thus, the optimal amount of catalyst is 50 mg for this EL to EP reaction. For comparison, we summarize the catalytic performance of other reported catalysts for the liquid phase catalytic oxidation of EL to EP in the presence of molecular oxygen. It should be mentioned that the gas phase [5,6,10,42,43], liquid phase using TBHP [12,38] or H2O2 [13] as the oxidant and photocatalytic [15,44] oxidation of alkyl lactate to alkyl pyruvate have also been extensively studied in the recent years. These catalyst systems are not included in this comparison. Table 4 shows that most of the reaction temperature adopted for this reaction is 130 °C, except for Na-OMS-2–2.5 mol% and Zn(NO3)2/VOC2O4 catalyst. For Na-OMS catalyst, a longer reaction time (12 h) was required to obtain a higher conversion. For Zn(NO3)2/VOC2O4 catalyst, the VOC2O4 as the organic compound could be dissolved in solvents, making it difficult to separate the catalyst. On the other hand, the vanadium-based catalysts showed much higher activity than the molybdenum-based catalyst (SnO2-MoO3) under similar reaction conditions. It is worth noting that the 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalyst in this work not only provided high EL conversion and EP selectivity in a short reaction time (3 h) but also had only half the vanadium loading of the 5.9 V x O y /SBA-15 catalyst. Considering both catalytic performance and economy, the 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalyst prepared in this work would be more suitable for EP production from EL. 3.2.3 Reusability of the catalyst The stability of catalyst is very important in heterogeneous catalysis. The reusability of catalyst was carried out by using 2 mmol of EL and 50 mg of 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15. Before the next cycle, the spent catalyst was washed with ethanol to remove any residue on the catalyst, and dried at 100 °C for 12 h. To our surprise, when acetonitrile was used as the solvent, the EL conversion dropped from 93% to 78% on the first cycle, possibly due to the CN being dissolved into acetonitrile. Therefore, several other solvents (acetone, N,N-dimethylformamide and diethyl succinate) were selected and studied their effects on the reaction (Table S1). The results showed that diethyl succinate as the solvent could offered the highest EL conversion (95.7%) and EP selectivity (99%), and thus was selected to study the reusability of catalyst. As shown in Fig. 7a, the EL conversion and EP selectivity remained fairly stable for the five successive cycles. Subsequently, to confirm the heterogeneous nature of the 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalyst, a hot filtration test was performed. After 1 h of the reaction, the EL conversion reached 29% (Fig. 7b), and the catalyst was removed from the solution by filtration, the filtrate continued to react at 130 °C for 2 h, and the EL conversion was almost unchanged, which proved that the active site was not dissolved into the reaction solution. Above results showed that the 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalyst has good activity and stability in the EL to EP reaction. 3.2.4 Effect of additives and the catalytic mechanism Previous studies have shown that doping nitrogen atoms in carbon materials could facilitate the oxidation reaction due to the action of pyridinic or pyrrolic nitrogen groups [14,17]. To further study the role of CN (the type of nitrogen) in V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalyst, nitrogen-containing additives such as pyridine and pyrrole was added, respectively, to the reaction solution with 2.7 V x O y /SBA-15 as the catalyst. To clearly show the effect of the addition on the reaction, we decreased the EL conversion to 43.6% by shortening the reaction time to 2 h. It can be seen from Fig. 8 that adding a small amount of pyridine (e.g., pyridine/EL = 0.1) to the solution could significantly increase the EL conversion, and the EL conversion increased from 43.6 to 68.7%. Meanwhile, the EP selectivity increased slightly from 93.5 to 98.9%. When the ratio of pyridine to EL increased slowly to 1.0, the EL conversion gradually increased to 91.5% and further increased the amount of pyridine (e.g., pyridine/EL = 2.0), the EL conversion decreased slightly to 88.3%, while the selectivity of EP was almost unchanged. Surprisingly, when a small amount of pyrrole (pyrrole /EL = 0.1) was added to the reaction, the EL conversion decreased rapidly from 43.6 to 13.1%, and the reaction was almost completely suppressed at a pyrrole /EL = 1.0. These results may indicate that the pyridinic-N rather than pyrrolic-N of the V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalyst accelerates the oxidation of EL to EP. A possible structure of V x O y /CN-SBA-15 ( Scheme 1) was then proposed based on the relevant literature on carbon nitride supported vanadia [49,50] and the present characterization result. In V x O y /CN-SBA-15, the V4+ cations were connected to Nb species of CN via coordinate-like interaction. According to the reported literature [14,18,41] and the above experiment, the possible catalytic mechanism was proposed and shown in Scheme 1. The reactant EL first interacts with pyridinic-N of CN via the hydrogen bonding (step I), and the oxygen atom of hydroxyl group was adsorbed on the V5+ of catalyst (step II). The β-hydrogen atom was then captured by the lattice oxygen of V x O y /CN-SBA-15 to form a five-membered intermediate (Step III). Finally, the desired product EP was formed by eliminating the β-hydrogen and the oxygen vacancy of the catalyst, accompanied by the generation of H2O (step IV and V). 4 Conclusion In summary, a series of highly efficient wV x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalysts were prepared by a simple impregnation method and employed for the oxidation of EL to EP reaction. The conversion of EL increased from 26.8 to 99.8% with increasing the vanadia loading from 0.5 to 4.8%, while the selectivity of EP was almost unchanged (about 98%). The 2.6V x O y /CN-SBA-15 was regarded as the optimum catalyst, giving a very high EL conversion (93.0%) under optimized reaction conditions (130 °C, 3 h in CH3CN), which was much higher than 2.7V x O y /SBA-15 (61.6%) and 2.7V x O y /CN (27.3%) catalysts. The catalyst characterization showed that the redox properties of 2.6V x O y /CN-SBA-15 were significantly improved after doping of CN, and thus improved the catalyst activity. Moreover, the addition of pyridine and pyrrole to the reaction solution increased and decreased the activity of the V x O y /SBA-15 catalyst, respectively, indicating that pyridinic-N of V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalyst may accelerate the oxidation of EL to EP. This study could provide a basis for not only developing more efficient solid catalysts for the oxidation of EL to EP reaction but also a good application in industry. coredata.dc:description: Development of high-performance heterogeneous catalysts for the selective oxidation of ethyl lactate (EL) to ethyl pyruvate (EP) is very important in the field of sustainable chemistry. In this work, a series of carbon nitride (CN) doped wV x O y /CN-SBA-15 (w = 0.5–4.8%) catalysts were prepared. The doping of CN could significantly enhance the activity of V x O y /CN-SBA-15 catalyst due to the synergistic effect of V species, CN and SBA-15. The 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 was identified as the most optimum catalyst, offering a high EL conversion (93.0%) and EP selectivity (98.7%) at 130 °C after 3 h of reaction. The O2-TPD and H2-TPR results confirmed that the redox properties of 2.6 V x O y /CN-SBA-15 are significantly improved compared with 2.7 V x O y /SBA-15, which plays an important role in the oxidation reaction. In addition, the control experiments indicated that the pyridinic-N rather than pyrrolic-N of the VxOy/CN-SBA-15 catalyst accelerated the oxidation of EL to EP.
coredata.dc:title: Carbon nitride doped V x O y /SBA-15 as highly efficient catalysts for the oxidation of ethyl lactate to ethyl pyruvate
